Overall, the verification and validation plan should include a combination of bench testing, on-road testing, and measurement of the vehicle's performance to ensure that it meets the design specifications and requirements. The plan should also include a timeline for testing and validation activities, as well as the resources required to carry out the plan.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Efficiency: Fuel efficient powertrain
System_Requirement: Transmission: Equip the vehicle with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) or an automated manual transmission (AMT) to reduce fuel consumption.
System_Architecture:
Automotive Systems Engineer:

The architecture of the Transmission system for a Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability, equipped with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) or an automated manual transmission (AMT) can be broken down into the following components:

1. Torque Converter: This component is only present in automatic transmissions. It is responsible for transferring torque from the engine to the transmission.

2. Transmission Control Unit (TCU): The TCU is the brain of the transmission system. It receives signals from various sensors and determines the appropriate gear ratio for the vehicle.

3. Gear Train: The gear train is a series of gears that transmit power from the engine to the wheels. In a CVT, the gear ratio is continuously variable, while in an AMT, the gear ratio is changed by an actuator that engages and disengages the clutch.

4. Clutch: The clutch is a mechanical device that connects and disconnects the engine from the transmission. In an AMT, the clutch is controlled by the TCU.

5. Shift Actuator: The shift actuator is responsible for changing the gear ratio in an AMT. It receives signals from the TCU to engage and disengage the clutch.

6. Gear Position Sensor: This sensor tells the TCU which gear the transmission is in. In a CVT, this is a continuously variable value, while in an AMT, it is discrete.

7. Throttle Position Sensor: This sensor tells the TCU how much the accelerator pedal is depressed. The TCU uses this information to determine the appropriate gear ratio for the vehicle.

8. Vehicle Speed Sensor: This sensor tells the TCU how fast the vehicle is traveling. The TCU uses this information to determine the appropriate gear ratio for the vehicle.

To map the interaction among components:

In a CVT, the engine is connected to the transmission via the torque converter. The TCU receives signals from the Throttle Position Sensor and Vehicle Speed Sensor to determine the appropriate gear ratio for the vehicle. The TCU then adjusts the gear ratio in the gear train to optimize fuel consumption.

In an AMT, the TCU controls the clutch and shift actuator to change the gear ratio. The TCU receives signals from the Throttle Position Sensor and Vehicle Speed Sensor to determine the appropriate gear ratio for the vehicle. The TCU then sends signals to the shift actuator to engage and disengage the clutch and change the gear ratio in the gear train.

Overall, the transmission system architecture for a Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability, equipped with a CVT or an AMT, is designed to optimize fuel consumption while maintaining smooth and efficient operation.
VandV_Plan:
, the following verification and validation plan can be implemented:

1. Functional Testing: Conduct functional testing of the transmission system to check whether it is performing as per the design requirements. This can be done by simulating different driving conditions and measuring the performance of the system. The test cases can include acceleration, deceleration, gear shifting, and fuel economy.

2. Environmental Testing: Conduct environmental testing of the transmission system to check whether it can operate under different environmental conditions. The test cases can include extreme temperatures, humidity, and altitude.

3. Durability Testing: Conduct durability testing of the transmission system to check whether it can withstand the expected lifespan of the vehicle. The test cases can include long term testing under different driving conditions and measuring the wear and tear of the system.

4. Safety Testing: Conduct safety testing of the transmission system to check whether it meets the safety standards. The test cases can include testing of the clutch and brake systems, emergency stop, and safety features like anti-lock braking system (ABS).

5. Compatibility Testing: Conduct compatibility testing of the transmission system with other vehicle systems like the engine, brakes, and suspension. This can be done by simulating different driving scenarios and measuring the performance of the system.

6. Usability Testing: Conduct usability testing of the transmission system to check whether it is user-friendly and easy to operate. The test cases can include testing of the gear shift mechanism, gear position indicator, and dashboard display.

7. Reliability Testing: Conduct reliability testing of the transmission system to check whether it can perform consistently over a long period of time. The test cases can include testing of the gear shift mechanism, clutch, and transmission fluid.

Overall, the verification and validation plan should ensure that the transmission system meets the design requirements, is safe and reliable, and can operate under different environmental conditions.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Efficiency: Fuel efficient powertrain
System_Requirement: Aerodynamics: Design the vehicle with an aerodynamic body shape and reduce air resistance to improve fuel efficiency.
System_Architecture:
Automotive Systems Engineer:

The architecture of the vehicle's aerodynamics consists of multiple components that work together to reduce air resistance and improve fuel efficiency. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture.

1. Body Shape: The vehicle's body shape is designed to be aerodynamic, with a streamlined shape that minimizes air resistance. The body shape is optimized to ensure that the air flows smoothly over the car, reducing turbulence and drag.

2. Front Air Dam: The front air dam is a component that is installed at the bottom of the front bumper. It helps to direct the airflow around the sides of the vehicle, reducing the amount of air that flows underneath the car. This reduces turbulence and drag, improving the vehicle's aerodynamics.

3. Rear Spoiler: The rear spoiler is a component that is installed at the back of the vehicle. It helps to reduce the amount of air that flows over the car, reducing the turbulence and drag that can occur at high speeds. This improves the vehicle's stability and fuel efficiency.

4. Underbody Panels: The underbody panels are components that are installed underneath the vehicle. They help to smooth out the airflow underneath the car, reducing turbulence and drag. This improves the vehicle's aerodynamics and fuel efficiency.

5. Wheel Design: The wheels are designed to be aerodynamic, with a shape that helps to reduce drag. The wheel design is optimized to ensure that the air flows smoothly over the wheels, reducing turbulence and drag.

6. Mirrors: The mirrors are designed to be aerodynamic, with a shape that helps to reduce drag. The mirror design is optimized to ensure that the air flows smoothly over the mirrors, reducing turbulence and drag.

7. Grille Design: The grille is designed to be aerodynamic, with a shape that helps to reduce drag. The grille design is optimized to ensure that the air flows smoothly through the grille, reducing turbulence and drag.

8. Windshield and Side Windows: The windshield and side windows are designed to be aerodynamic, with a shape that helps to reduce drag. The window design is optimized to ensure that the air flows smoothly over the windows, reducing turbulence and drag.

To map the interaction among components:

The aerodynamic body shape, front air dam, rear spoiler, underbody panels, wheel design, mirrors, grille design, windshield, and side windows all work together to reduce the amount of air resistance that the vehicle experiences while driving. This reduces the turbulence and drag, improving the vehicle's fuel efficiency. The overall design of the vehicle is optimized to ensure that the air flows smoothly over the car, reducing turbulence and drag.
VandV_Plan:
Verification and Validation Plan:

1. Verification of Body Shape:
- Conduct Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the body shape is aerodynamic and reduces air resistance.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

2. Verification of Front Air Dam:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the front air dam directs airflow around the sides of the vehicle, reducing the amount of air that flows underneath the car.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

3. Verification of Rear Spoiler:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the rear spoiler reduces the amount of air that flows over the car, improving stability and fuel efficiency.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

4. Verification of Underbody Panels:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the underbody panels smooth out the airflow underneath the car, reducing turbulence and drag.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

5. Verification of Wheel Design:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the wheel design is aerodynamic and reduces drag.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

6. Verification of Mirror Design:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the mirror design is aerodynamic and reduces drag.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

7. Verification of Grille Design:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the grille design is aerodynamic and reduces drag.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

8. Verification of Windshield and Side Windows:
- Conduct CFD simulations and wind tunnel tests to ensure the window design is aerodynamic and reduces drag.
- Compare the results with the design requirements and industry standards.

Validation:
- Conduct on-road tests under different driving conditions to validate the aerodynamic features of the vehicle.
- Measure the fuel efficiency and compare it with the design requirements and industry standards.
- Evaluate the handling and stability of the vehicle under different driving conditions and compare it with the design requirements and industry standards.

Overall, the verification and validation plan would ensure that the aerodynamic features of the vehicle are optimized and meet the design requirements and industry standards.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Efficiency: Fuel efficient powertrain
System_Requirement: Regenerative Braking System: Install a regenerative braking system that converts kinetic energy into electrical energy to recharge the battery and reduce fuel consumption.
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Regenerative Braking System consists of multiple key components that ensure the smooth operation and efficient energy conversion. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture.

1. Electric Motor: Consider this as the 'heart' of the operation. The Electric Motor is responsible for generating the kinetic energy as well as generating electrical energy during regenerative braking.

2. Battery Pack: This is the energy storage unit that stores the electrical energy generated during regenerative braking. It also provides power to the electric motor during acceleration.

3. Power Electronics: This component is responsible for managing the flow of energy between the electric motor and the battery pack. It also converts the kinetic energy generated during braking into electrical energy and sends it to the battery pack.

4. Braking System: This system is responsible for slowing down the vehicle during braking. In a regenerative braking system, the braking system works in conjunction with the electric motor to convert kinetic energy into electrical energy.

5. Control Module: This component monitors the vehicle speed, accelerator pedal position, and brake pedal position to determine when regenerative braking is required. It also controls the flow of energy between the electric motor and the battery pack.

6. User Interface: This can be a physical switch or digital interface within the cockpit which is operated by the driver to initiate the regenerative braking.

To map the interaction among components:
The driver initiates the regenerative braking through the User Interface => The Control Module receives the input and processes it => It then communicates with the Power Electronics, which converts the kinetic energy during braking into electrical energy and sends it to the Battery Pack => The Battery Pack stores the electrical energy and provides power to the Electric Motor during acceleration => During braking, the Braking System works in conjunction with the Electric Motor to slow down the vehicle and convert kinetic energy into electrical energy => The Control Module uses data from various sensors to determine when regenerative braking is required and optimizes the flow of energy between the Electric Motor and Battery Pack.

To note, the Regenerative Braking System operates in tandem with the vehicle's conventional braking system to ensure optimal braking performance and safety. Additionally, the installation of this system reduces fuel consumption and enhances the overall energy efficiency of the vehicle, making it an ideal choice for an urban mobility vehicle with a focus on sustainability.
VandV_Plan:
Verification and Validation Plan:

1. Electric Motor:
- Verification: The electric motor specifications and performance parameters will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Regenerative Braking System.
- Validation: The electric motor will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure it generates the required kinetic energy and electrical energy during acceleration and regenerative braking.

2. Battery Pack:
- Verification: The battery pack specifications, performance parameters, and safety features will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Regenerative Braking System.
- Validation: The battery pack will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure it stores the electrical energy generated during regenerative braking and provides power to the electric motor during acceleration.

3. Power Electronics:
- Verification: The power electronics specifications and performance parameters will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Regenerative Braking System.
- Validation: The power electronics will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure they manage the flow of energy between the electric motor and the battery pack efficiently and convert kinetic energy during braking into electrical energy.

4. Braking System:
- Verification: The braking system specifications and performance parameters will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Regenerative Braking System.
- Validation: The braking system will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure it works in conjunction with the electric motor to slow down the vehicle during regenerative braking and ensures optimal braking performance and safety.

5. Control Module:
- Verification: The control module specifications and performance parameters will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Regenerative Braking System.
- Validation: The control module will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure it accurately monitors the vehicle speed, accelerator pedal position, and brake pedal position to determine when regenerative braking is required and optimizes the flow of energy between the electric motor and the battery pack.

6. User Interface:
- Verification: The user interface specifications and performance parameters will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Regenerative Braking System.
- Validation: The user interface will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure it accurately initiates the regenerative braking and communicates with the control module.

Overall System:
- Verification: The Regenerative Braking System specifications and performance parameters will be verified to ensure they meet the requirements of the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability.
- Validation: The Regenerative Braking System will be tested under various operating conditions to ensure it reduces fuel consumption, enhances the overall energy efficiency of the vehicle, and provides optimal braking performance and safety. 

Testing of the Regenerative Braking System will be conducted in a controlled environment and on-road to ensure all components function as intended under normal and extreme conditions.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Efficiency: Fuel efficient powertrain
System_Requirement: Low Rolling Resistance Tires: Outfit the vehicle with low rolling resistance tires to reduce friction and improve fuel economy.
System_Architecture:
The architecture of Low Rolling Resistance Tires for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle consists of multiple key components that work together to achieve better fuel economy. Here is a detailed layout of the architecture.

1. Low Rolling Resistance Tires: The first and most important component is the tires themselves. Low Rolling Resistance Tires are engineered to reduce the amount of friction between the tire and the road surface. This is achieved by using specialized rubber compounds, unique tread patterns, and other design features that help to minimize energy loss due to rolling resistance.

2. Wheel Rims: The next component is the wheel rims. In order for the Low Rolling Resistance Tires to work effectively, they need to be mounted on rims that are compatible with their size and shape. The rims provide a secure mounting surface for the tires and help to maintain their shape and structure under load.

3. Suspension System: The suspension system plays an important role in ensuring that the tires make optimal contact with the road surface. It helps to absorb shocks and vibrations that can affect the tire's performance, and it also helps to maintain proper alignment and balance.

4. Braking System: The braking system is another critical component that works in tandem with the Low Rolling Resistance Tires. The reduced rolling resistance of the tires means that less force is required to slow down or stop the vehicle. This can lead to shorter stopping distances, improved brake pad life, and reduced wear and tear on the braking system as a whole.

5. Electronic Control Unit (ECU): The ECU is the central component that controls all of the vehicle's systems. In the case of Low Rolling Resistance Tires, the ECU can be programmed to adjust various settings based on the type of road surface, driving conditions, and other factors. This can help to optimize fuel economy and ensure that the tires are working at their best.

To map the interaction among components:
The Low Rolling Resistance Tires are mounted on the wheel rims and interact with the road surface => The suspension system helps to maintain proper alignment and balance => The ECU monitors driving conditions and adjusts settings as needed => The braking system is optimized to work with the reduced rolling resistance of the tires => The result is improved fuel economy and overall performance.

Verification and Validation Plan:

1. Low Rolling Resistance Tires:
- Verify the tire specifications and compare them with the design requirements
- Validate the tire performance by conducting tests to measure the rolling resistance, wear and tear, and durability
- Verify the compatibility of the tires with the wheel rims specified for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle
- Validate the tire performance on different types of road surfaces and in different weather conditions

2. Wheel Rims:
- Verify the compatibility of the wheel rims with the Low Rolling Resistance Tires specified for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle
- Validate the wheel rim performance by conducting tests to measure their strength, durability, and compatibility with the suspension system
- Verify the wheel rim specifications and compare them with the design requirements

3. Suspension System:
- Verify the compatibility of the suspension system with the Low Rolling Resistance Tires and wheel rims specified for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle
- Validate the suspension system performance by conducting tests to measure its ability to absorb shocks and vibrations, maintain proper alignment and balance, and ensure optimal contact between the tires and road surface
- Verify the suspension system specifications and compare them with the design requirements

4. Braking System:
- Verify the compatibility of the braking system with the Low Rolling Resistance Tires specified for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle
- Validate the braking system performance by conducting tests to measure its ability to work with the reduced rolling resistance of the tires, ensure shorter stopping distances, and reduce wear and tear on the braking system as a whole
- Verify the braking system specifications and compare them with the design requirements

5. Electronic Control Unit (ECU):
- Verify the compatibility of the ECU with the Low Rolling Resistance Tires, wheel rims, suspension system, and braking system specified for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle
- Validate the ECU performance by conducting tests to measure its ability to monitor driving conditions and adjust settings as needed to optimize fuel economy and ensure that the tires are working at their best
- Verify the ECU specifications and compare them with the design requirements

Overall System:
- Verify the compatibility and integration of all components specified for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle
- Validate the overall system performance by conducting tests to measure fuel economy, maneuverability, and overall performance in different driving conditions and on different types of road surfaces
- Verify the system specifications and compare them with the design requirements.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Efficiency: Fuel efficient powertrain
System_Requirement: Engine Start/Stop System: Implement an engine start/stop system that shuts off the engine when the vehicle is idle and restarts it when the accelerator is pressed, reducing fuel consumption.
System_Architecture:
The architecture of an Engine Start/Stop system is based on multiple key components that ensure a smooth operation and the reduction of fuel consumption. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability:

1. Control Module: This component is responsible for interpreting signals from various sensors and initiating the start/stop operation of the engine. It also monitors the battery level, engine temperature and other important parameters.

2. Engine Sensor: This sensor measures the RPM and position of the engine and relays this information to the Control Module.

3. Brake Pedal Sensor: This sensor detects when the brake pedal is depressed, indicating that the vehicle is stationary.

4. Accelerator Pedal Sensor: This sensor detects when the accelerator pedal is pressed, signaling the Control Module to restart the engine.

5. Battery System: This component provides the necessary electrical power to the vehicle when the engine is off, ensuring the smooth operation of the vehicle's electrical systems.

6. Starter System: This system is responsible for starting the engine when the accelerator is pressed. It can be electromechanical or electric.

7. Ignition System: This system is responsible for igniting the fuel-air mixture in the engine's combustion chamber, which starts the engine. It can be either a conventional spark ignition or a compression ignition system.

8. Fuel System: This system supplies fuel to the engine, ensuring that it has the necessary fuel-air mixture to start and operate efficiently.

9. Transmission System: This system is responsible for transmitting power from the engine to the wheels, allowing the vehicle to move.

To map the interaction among components:

When the vehicle is stopped, the Brake Pedal Sensor detects that the brake pedal is depressed and signals the Control Module. The Control Module then shuts off the engine, using information from the Engine Sensor to ensure that the engine is not stopped during critical operations.

When the accelerator pedal is pressed, the Accelerator Pedal Sensor detects this and signals the Control Module to restart the engine. The Control Module then sends a signal to the Starter System to start the engine, and the Ignition System ignites the fuel-air mixture in the engine's combustion chamber, allowing the engine to start.

The Fuel System supplies fuel to the engine, and the Transmission System transmits the power from the engine to the wheels, allowing the vehicle to move.

Finally, the Battery System ensures that the vehicle's electrical systems continue to operate smoothly even when the engine is off, reducing fuel consumption and emissions.
VandV_Plan:
Verification and Validation Plan:

1. Control Module:
- Verify that the Control Module accurately interprets signals from all sensors and initiates the start/stop operation of the engine.
- Validate that the Control Module monitors the battery level, engine temperature, and other important parameters accurately.

2. Engine Sensor:

3. Brake Pedal Sensor:

4. Accelerator Pedal Sensor:

5. Battery System:
- Verify that the Battery System provides the necessary electrical power to the vehicle when the engine is off, ensuring the smooth operation of the vehicle's electrical systems.
- Validate that the Battery System operates efficiently and reduces fuel consumption and emissions.

6. Starter System:
- Verify that the Starter System starts the engine when the accelerator is pressed.
- Validate that the Starter System operates efficiently and reduces fuel consumption and emissions.

7. Ignition System:
- Verify that the Ignition System ignites the fuel-air mixture in the engine's combustion chamber, which starts the engine.
- Validate that the Ignition System operates efficiently and reduces fuel consumption and emissions.

System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Navigation System for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle is designed to provide optimal routes and real-time traffic updates to minimize fuel consumption and reduce travel time. Here is a detailed layout of the architecture:

1. GPS Receiver: This is the primary component of the Navigation System that receives signals from GPS satellites to determine the vehicle's location and speed.

2. Navigation Software: This software uses the GPS data to calculate the optimal route to the destination. The software considers various factors such as road speed limits, traffic congestion, and road closures to provide the best possible route.

3. Map Data: The Navigation System relies on detailed map data that contains information about roads, highways, and landmarks. The map data is stored in a digital format on a hard drive or solid-state drive.

4. User Interface: The Navigation System can be accessed via a touch screen display or voice commands. The user interface displays the map, route, and other relevant information such as estimated travel time, distance to destination, and fuel consumption.

5. Traffic Data: Real-time traffic data is provided by a Traffic Message Channel (TMC) receiver or cellular data connection. The Navigation System uses this data to re-calculate the route if there is traffic congestion or road closures.

6. Fuel Consumption Data: The Navigation System can incorporate data from the vehicle's fuel consumption sensors to provide the most fuel-efficient route. This data is used to calculate the optimal speed and route for the vehicle to minimize fuel consumption.

7. Short Turn Radius and Good Navigability: The Navigation System takes into account the vehicle's short turn radius and good navigability to provide routes that are suitable for the compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle. The system will avoid roads that are too narrow or have sharp turns that the vehicle cannot handle.

8. Integration with other systems: The Navigation System can be integrated with other systems such as the vehicle's entertainment system, climate control, and smartphone apps. This allows for a seamless user experience and provides additional functionality such as hands-free calling and music streaming.

In summary, the Navigation System for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle is designed to provide optimal routes and real-time traffic updates to minimize fuel consumption and reduce travel time. Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Efficiency: Fuel efficient powertrain
System_Requirement: Short Turn Radius: Design the vehicle with a short turn radius to improve navigability in urban areas and reduce fuel consumption.
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Short Turn Radius system consists of multiple key components that work together to improve the vehicle's navigability in urban areas and reduce fuel consumption. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture:

1. Steering System: The steering system is the primary component responsible for turning the front wheels of the vehicle. The system consists of a steering wheel, steering column, steering gearbox, and steering linkage. In a compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicle, the steering system is designed to be highly responsive to the driver's input, allowing for quick and precise turns with minimal effort.

2. Suspension System: The suspension system plays a critical role in the vehicle's ability to make tight turns. The system is designed to provide a stable and comfortable ride while also allowing the wheels to turn at extreme angles. In a compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicle, the suspension system is optimized for maneuverability, with a focus on minimizing body roll and maximizing wheel articulation.

3. Tires: The tires are an essential component in the Short Turn Radius system. The tires must be designed to provide maximum grip and traction during turns while also being durable and fuel-efficient. In a compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicle, the tires are designed to be small and narrow, allowing for a tight turning radius while also minimizing rolling resistance.

4. Electronic Control Unit (ECU): The ECU is the brain of the Short Turn Radius system. It receives input from various sensors throughout the vehicle and uses this information to control the steering and suspension systems. In a compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicle, the ECU is programmed to optimize the vehicle's turning radius while also minimizing fuel consumption.

5. Sensors: The sensors are critical components in the Short Turn Radius system. They provide the ECU with real-time information about the vehicle's speed, steering angle, and suspension position. In a compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicle, the sensors are strategically placed throughout the vehicle to provide the ECU with the most accurate data possible.

6. Electric Power Steering (EPS): In some compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicles, an Electric Power Steering system is used instead of a hydraulic system. EPS is more efficient and provides a more precise steering feel. It can also be programmed to provide more assistance during low-speed maneuvers, further improving the vehicle's turning radius.

To map the interaction among components:
The driver turns the steering wheel => The Steering System turns the front wheels => The Suspension System allows the wheels to turn at extreme angles => The Tires provide maximum grip and traction during turns => The Sensors provide real-time information about the vehicle's speed, steering angle, and suspension position => The ECU receives this information and uses it to control the Steering and Suspension Systems => The EPS provides assistance during low-speed maneuvers and further improves the vehicle's turning radius. 

Overall, the Short Turn Radius system in a compact hatchback 2-seater urban mobility vehicle is designed to provide maximum maneuverability in tight urban spaces while also minimizing fuel consumption. By optimizing the steering, suspension, tires, and electronic control systems, the vehicle can make tight turns with ease, improving navigability and reducing fuel consumption.

System_Requirement: Collision Avoidance System: Advanced sensors and algorithms to detect and avoid potential collisions with other vehicles and obstacles on the road
System_Architecture:
Automotive Systems Engineer:

The architecture of the Collision Avoidance System for the Compact Hatchback 2 Seater Urban Mobility Vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability involves several key components that work together to detect and avoid potential collisions with other vehicles and obstacles on the road. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture:

1. Sensor Suite: This is the primary component of the Collision Avoidance System, consisting of advanced sensors such as LiDAR, radar, and cameras that provide a 360-degree view of the vehicle's surroundings. These sensors continuously gather information about other vehicles, pedestrians, and obstacles on the road.

2. Control Module: The Control Module is the brain of the system, which interprets the data collected by the Sensor Suite and processes it using advanced algorithms to detect potential collision risks. It then sends signals to the actuator and warning systems to take corrective action.

3. Actuator: The Actuator is responsible for taking corrective actions such as applying the brakes, steering the vehicle, or adjusting the throttle to avoid potential collisions. It works in conjunction with the Control Module to determine the best course of action based on the data collected by the Sensor Suite.

4. Warning Systems: The Warning Systems are designed to alert the driver of potential collision risks. They include visual and audible alerts that notify the driver of potential hazards and provide instructions on how to avoid them.

5. Navigation System: The Navigation System provides the Control Module with information about the vehicle's location, speed, and direction of travel. This data is used in conjunction with the Sensor Suite to determine potential collision risks.

6. Communication Systems: The Communication Systems are used to communicate with other vehicles on the road and exchange information about their location, speed, and direction of travel. This information is used to detect potential collision risks and take corrective action.

To map the interaction among components:

The Sensor Suite continuously gathers data about the vehicle's surroundings => The Control Module interprets the data using advanced algorithms to detect potential collision risks => The Actuator takes corrective action by applying the brakes, steering the vehicle, or adjusting the throttle => The Warning Systems alert the driver of potential hazards and provide instructions on how to avoid them => The Navigation System provides the Control Module with information about the vehicle's location, speed, and direction of travel => The Communication Systems exchange information with other vehicles on the road to detect potential collision risks and take corrective action.

It's important to note that the Collision Avoidance System operates in tandem with other systems such as the Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) and Electronic Stability Control (ESC) to ensure optimal system performance and safety.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Safety: Equipped with necessary safety features
System_Requirement: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS): Prevents the wheels from locking up during braking, ensuring stable and controlled stopping distance on slippery or uneven roads
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) consists of multiple key components that ensure the smooth operation and effective braking of the vehicle. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture.

1. Wheel Speed Sensors: These sensors are installed at all four wheels and measure the rotational speed of the wheels. The readings from these sensors are used to detect if the wheels are locking up during braking.

2. Electronic Control Unit (ECU): This is the brain of the ABS system. It receives input from the wheel speed sensors and uses this information to control the braking force at each wheel.

3. Hydraulic Control Unit (HCU): This unit is responsible for controlling the hydraulic pressure to each wheel brake cylinder. It receives signals from the ECU and adjusts the pressure to prevent wheel lockup.

4. Brake Pedal Sensor: This sensor detects the amount of force applied to the brake pedal by the driver. It sends this information to the ECU, which uses it to determine the appropriate amount of braking force to apply to each wheel.

5. Brake Booster: This component amplifies the force applied to the brake pedal by the driver, making it easier to slow down or stop the vehicle.

6. Brake Calipers/Rotors/Drums: These mechanical components are responsible for slowing down the vehicle by applying friction to the wheels. The ABS system controls the hydraulic pressure applied to these components to prevent wheel lockup.

7. Warning Light: This light is located on the dashboard and indicates when the ABS system is activated or if there is a malfunction in the system.

To map the interaction among components:
When the driver applies the brakes, the Brake Pedal Sensor detects the force applied and sends this information to the ECU. The ECU then uses the input from the Wheel Speed Sensors to determine if any of the wheels are locking up. If the ECU detects a wheel lockup, it sends a signal to the HCU to adjust the hydraulic pressure to that wheel. The HCU then adjusts the pressure to prevent the wheel from locking up, ensuring stable and controlled stopping distance on slippery or uneven roads. The Brake Booster amplifies the force applied to the brake pedal by the driver, making it easier to slow down or stop the vehicle. The Brake Calipers/Rotors/Drums apply friction to the wheels to slow down the vehicle, with the ABS system controlling the hydraulic pressure applied to these components to prevent wheel lockup. The Warning Light on the dashboard indicates when the ABS system is activated or if there is a malfunction in the system, alerting the driver to any potential issues.
VandV_Plan:
Verification and Validation Plan:

1. Wheel Speed Sensor Testing:
- Verify that the wheel speed sensors are installed at all four wheels and are functioning correctly
- Validate that the readings from the sensors are accurate and consistent
- Test the system's ability to detect wheel lockup and adjust braking force accordingly

2. Electronic Control Unit (ECU) Testing:
- Verify that the ECU is receiving input from the wheel speed sensors and brake pedal sensor
- Validate the ECU's ability to control the braking force at each wheel based on the input received
- Test the system's ability to prevent wheel lockup and ensure stable stopping distance

3. Hydraulic Control Unit (HCU) Testing:
- Verify that the HCU is receiving signals from the ECU and adjusting the hydraulic pressure to each wheel brake cylinder
- Validate the HCU's ability to prevent wheel lockup and ensure stable stopping distance
- Test the system's ability to adjust hydraulic pressure in real-time and maintain stability on slippery or uneven roads

4. Brake Pedal Sensor Testing:
- Verify that the brake pedal sensor is detecting the amount of force applied by the driver accurately
- Validate that the input from the sensor is being used by the ECU to determine the appropriate amount of braking force to apply to each wheel
- Test the system's ability to adjust braking force based on the input from the brake pedal sensor in real-time

5. Brake Booster Testing:
- Verify that the brake booster is amplifying the force applied to the brake pedal by the driver
- Validate that the amplification is consistent and accurate, making it easier to slow down or stop the vehicle
- Test the system's ability to adjust braking force based on the input from the brake booster in real-time

6. Brake Calipers/Rotors/Drums Testing:
- Verify that the mechanical components are functioning correctly and applying friction to the wheels
- Validate that the ABS system is controlling the hydraulic pressure applied to these components to prevent wheel lockup
- Test the system's ability to adjust hydraulic pressure in real-time and maintain stability on slippery or uneven roads

7. Warning Light Testing:
- Verify that the warning light is functioning correctly and indicating when the ABS system is activated or if there is a malfunction in the system
- Validate that the warning light is visible to the driver and clearly indicates any potential issues with the system

Overall, the ABS system for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability should be tested in various simulated and real-world driving conditions to ensure that it is performing according to the specification and providing safe and reliable braking performance.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Safety: Equipped with necessary safety features
System_Requirement: Electronic Stability Control (ESC): Automatically applies brakes to individual wheels and reduces engine power to prevent skidding and loss of control in emergency maneuvers
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Electronic Stability Control (ESC) system for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle is a complex system that involves multiple key components that work together to ensure optimal performance in emergency situations. Here is a detailed architecture of the ESC system:

1. Wheel Speed Sensors: These sensors are placed on each wheel and measure the speed of rotation. The data is sent to the Electronic Control Unit (ECU) to determine if there is a difference in wheel speed, which can indicate a potential skid.

2. Steering Angle Sensor: This sensor measures the angle of the steering wheel. The data is used by the ECU to determine the intended direction of the vehicle.

3. Accelerometer: This component measures the lateral acceleration of the vehicle. The data is sent to the ECU to detect if the vehicle is turning too quickly and potentially losing control.

4. Brake Pressure Sensor: This sensor measures the hydraulic pressure of each brake circuit. The data is sent to the ECU to detect if there is a difference in braking pressure between the wheels, which could indicate a potential skid.

5. Electronic Control Unit (ECU): This is the "brain" of the ESC system. It receives data from the various sensors and uses algorithms to determine if the vehicle is in danger of losing control. If necessary, the ECU will send signals to actuate the brakes and reduce engine power to prevent skidding and loss of control.

6. Actuators: These are components that receive signals from the ECU and actuate the brakes. The ESC system has a separate actuator for each wheel, allowing it to brake individual wheels to prevent skidding.

7. Engine Control Module (ECM): This module is responsible for controlling the engine's power output. It receives signals from the ECU and can reduce engine power if necessary to prevent skidding.

8. Brake System: The brake system is an essential component of the ESC system. It must be in good working order to ensure the ESC system can actuate the brakes and prevent skidding.

To map the interaction among components:
The Wheel Speed Sensors, Steering Angle Sensor, Accelerometer, and Brake Pressure Sensors send data to the ECU => The ECU processes this data and determines if the vehicle is in danger of skidding => If necessary, the ECU sends signals to the Actuators, which actuate the brakes and reduce engine power to prevent skidding => The Brake System must be in good working order to ensure the Actuators can properly brake individual wheels => The ECM can reduce engine power if necessary to assist the ESC system.

Overall, the ESC system is a critical safety feature that helps prevent accidents in emergency situations. It is designed to work seamlessly with other components of the vehicle to ensure optimal performance and safety.
VandV_Plan:
Verification Plan:

1. Wheel Speed Sensors: 
- Verify that each wheel speed sensor is positioned correctly and is functioning properly.
- Verify that the sensors are sending the correct data to the ECU.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the ECU is correctly interpreting the data from the sensors.

2. Steering Angle Sensor:
- Verify that the steering angle sensor is placed correctly and is functioning properly.
- Verify that the sensor is sending the correct data to the ECU.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the ECU is correctly interpreting the data from the sensor.

3. Accelerometer:
- Verify that the accelerometer is placed correctly and is functioning properly.
- Verify that the sensor is sending the correct data to the ECU.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the ECU is correctly interpreting the data from the sensor.

4. Brake Pressure Sensor:
- Verify that each brake pressure sensor is positioned properly and is functioning correctly.
- Verify that the sensors are sending the correct data to the ECU.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the ECU is correctly interpreting the data from the sensors.

5. Electronic Control Unit (ECU):
- Verify that the ECU is receiving the correct data from all sensors.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the ECU is accurately processing the data and making the correct decisions to prevent skidding.
- Verify that the ECU is sending the correct signals to the actuators and the ECM.

6. Actuators:
- Verify that the actuators are receiving the correct signals from the ECU.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the actuators are functioning properly and braking each wheel as needed to prevent skidding.

7. Engine Control Module (ECM):
- Verify that the ECM is receiving the correct signals from the ECU.
- Conduct a test to ensure that the ECM is reducing engine power as needed to prevent skidding.

8. Brake System:
- Verify that the brake system is in good working order and is capable of functioning properly with the ESC system.

Validation Plan:

1. Conduct a series of tests to ensure that the ESC system is functioning properly under various driving conditions, such as wet roads, icy roads, and sharp turns.

2. Conduct a test to ensure that the ESC system is able to prevent skidding and maintain control of the vehicle in emergency situations.

3. Conduct a test to ensure that the ESC system is not interfering with the normal operation of the vehicle under normal driving conditions.

4. Conduct a test to ensure that the ESC system is able to function properly with other safety systems, such as airbags and seat belts.

5. Conduct a test to ensure that the ESC system is able to function properly with other control systems, such as the vehicle's navigation system.

Overall, the verification and validation plan for the ESC system should ensure that the system is functioning properly and is able to prevent skidding and maintain control of the vehicle in emergency situations. The plan should also ensure that the system is not interfering with the normal operation of the vehicle and is able to function properly with other safety and control systems.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Safety: Equipped with necessary safety features
System_Requirement: Lane Departure Warning System (LDWS): Alerts the driver when the vehicle drifts out of the lane without signaling, reducing the risk of collision with other vehicles or objects on the road
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Lane Departure Warning System (LDWS) comprises several components that work together to detect when the vehicle drifts out of the lane and alert the driver to take corrective action. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture.

1. Camera Sensor: This component is installed on the windshield or front grille of the vehicle to capture images of the road ahead. The camera can detect lane markings and analyze the vehicle's position relative to them.

2. Image Processing Module: It processes the input from the camera sensor and applies computer vision algorithms to detect the lane markings on the road. It also calculates the distance between the vehicle and the markings to determine if the vehicle is drifting out of the lane.

3. Control Module: This acts as the central processing unit of the LDWS and receives input from the image processing module. It analyzes the data and activates the warning system if the vehicle is drifting out of the lane.

4. Warning System: This is the component that alerts the driver if the vehicle is drifting out of the lane. The warning can be in the form of a visual warning on the dashboard or an audible alert that sounds from the car's speakers.

5. User Interface: This can be a physical switch or digital interface within the cockpit which is operated by the driver to enable or disable the LDWS system.

To map the interaction among components:
The camera sensor captures images of the road ahead => The images are processed by the Image Processing Module => The Control Module receives input from the Image Processing Module and activates the warning system if the vehicle is drifting out of the lane => The Warning System alerts the driver with a visual or audible warning => The User Interface allows the driver to enable or disable the LDWS system.

It's worth noting that the LDWS system operates optimally under certain conditions, including clear lane markings, good weather conditions, and minimal glare from sunlight or headlights. Additionally, the LDWS system is designed to complement the driver's actions and not replace them, so it's essential to keep the driver engaged and vigilant while driving.
VandV_Plan:
Verification and Validation Plan for LDWS System:

1. Requirements Review and Analysis:
Review and analyze the functional and non-functional requirements of the LDWS system. Ensure that the architecture and components meet these requirements.

2. Unit Testing:
Perform unit testing on each component of the LDWS system to ensure that they function correctly and meet the specified requirements. This includes testing the camera sensor, image processing module, control module, warning system, and user interface.

3. Integration Testing:
Perform integration testing to ensure that the individual components of the LDWS system work together seamlessly to achieve the desired functionality. This includes testing the interaction between the camera sensor, image processing module, control module, warning system, and user interface.

4. System Testing:
Perform system testing to ensure that the LDWS system works as intended in real-world scenarios. This includes testing the LDWS system under various driving conditions, such as different weather conditions, lighting conditions, and road types.

5. Performance Testing:
Perform performance testing to ensure that the LDWS system meets the performance requirements. This includes testing the accuracy and response time of the LDWS system under different driving conditions.

6. Usability Testing:
Perform usability testing to ensure that the LDWS system is user-friendly and easy to use for drivers. This includes testing the user interface and ensuring that drivers can easily enable or disable the LDWS system.

7. Regression Testing:
Perform regression testing to ensure that any changes or updates to the LDWS system do not affect its functionality or performance.

8. Compliance Testing:
Perform compliance testing to ensure that the LDWS system meets all applicable regulations, standards, and guidelines.

9. Field Testing:
Perform field testing in a real-world environment to ensure that the LDWS system works as intended in actual driving situations.

10. Maintenance and Support:
Provide ongoing maintenance and support for the LDWS system to ensure that it continues to function properly and meet the specified requirements.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Safety: Equipped with necessary safety features
System_Requirement: Blind Spot Monitoring System (BSM): Detects other vehicles in the blind spot and warns the driver with visual or audible signals, reducing the risk of collision during lane changes or merging
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Blind Spot Monitoring System (BSM) for a compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle with short turn radius and good navigability consists of multiple key components that ensure accurate detection and timely warning to the driver. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture.

1. Blind Spot Detection Sensors: These sensors are the primary components responsible for detecting other vehicles in the blind spot. They are usually mounted on the rear bumper or side mirrors of the vehicle and use radar or ultrasonic technology to detect other vehicles.

2. Control Module: Consider this as the 'brain' of the operation. The Control Module receives signals from the Blind Spot Detection Sensors and processes this data to determine if there is a vehicle in the blind spot.

3. Driver Interface: This can be a visual or audible warning signal that alerts the driver of the presence of a vehicle in the blind spot. This signal is transmitted to the Control Module.

4. Turn Signal Indicator: This sensor detects when the driver activates the turn signal and sends this signal to the Control Module. This input helps the system determine if the driver is intending to change lanes or merge.

5. Vehicle Speed Sensor: This sensor measures the speed of the vehicle and sends this data to the Control Module. This information is used to determine if the vehicle is traveling at a speed that would make a lane change or merging unsafe.

6. Warning Signal Indicator: This component generates the visual or audible warning signal to alert the driver of the presence of a vehicle in the blind spot. The signal is triggered by the Control Module based on the input from Blind Spot Detection Sensors and other sensors.

To map the interaction among components:
The Blind Spot Detection Sensors detect other vehicles in the blind spot => The Control Module then processes this data along with inputs from the Turn Signal Indicator and Vehicle Speed Sensor => It then determines if there is a risk of collision during a lane change or merging => If there is a risk, the Control Module sends a signal to the Warning Signal Indicator to alert the driver of the presence of a vehicle in the blind spot => The driver can then take appropriate action to avoid a collision.

To note, the Blind Spot Monitoring System operates in tandem with other safety systems in the vehicle, such as the Forward Collision Warning System and Lane Departure Warning System, to provide a comprehensive safety net for the driver.
VandV_Plan:
Verification and Validation Plan for the Blind Spot Monitoring System for a Compact Hatchback 2 Seater Urban Mobility Vehicle:

1. Blind Spot Detection Sensors:
    a. Verification:
        i. Ensure that the sensors are installed in the correct location on the vehicle.
        ii. Conduct testing to ensure that the sensors are detecting other vehicles accurately in the blind spot.
        iii. Verify that the sensors are functioning properly under different weather and lighting conditions.
    b. Validation:
        i. Conduct field testing to ensure that the sensors are detecting other vehicles accurately in real-world driving conditions.
        ii. Verify that the sensors are detecting all types of vehicles (e.g. cars, trucks, motorcycles).

2. Control Module:
    a. Verification:
        i. Test the Control Module to ensure that it is processing data from the sensors accurately.
        ii. Verify that the Control Module is providing the correct output to the Warning Signal Indicator.
        iii. Conduct testing to ensure that the Control Module is functioning properly under different weather and lighting conditions.
    b. Validation:
        i. Conduct field testing to ensure that the Control Module is providing accurate warnings to the driver in real-world driving conditions.
        ii. Verify that the Control Module is functioning properly in all driving scenarios (e.g. merging, changing lanes, driving on the highway).

3. Driver Interface:
    a. Verification:
        i. Test the visual or audible warning signal to ensure that it is working properly.
        ii. Verify that the warning signal is activated when there is a vehicle in the blind spot.
        iii. Conduct testing to ensure that the warning signal is visible or audible to the driver under different weather and lighting conditions.
    b. Validation:
        i. Conduct field testing to ensure that the warning signal is visible or audible to the driver in real-world driving conditions.
        ii. Verify that the warning signal is effective in alerting the driver of the presence of a vehicle in the blind spot.

4. Turn Signal Indicator:
    a. Verification:
        i. Test the Turn Signal Indicator to ensure that it is working properly.
        ii. Verify that the Turn Signal Indicator is providing the correct input to the Control Module.
    b. Validation:
        i. Conduct field testing to ensure that the Turn Signal Indicator is providing accurate input to the Control Module in real-world driving conditions.
        ii. Verify that the Turn Signal Indicator is functioning properly in all driving scenarios (e.g. merging, changing lanes, driving on the highway).

5. Vehicle Speed Sensor:
    a. Verification:
        i. Test the Vehicle Speed Sensor to ensure that it is measuring the speed of the vehicle accurately.
        ii. Verify that the Vehicle Speed Sensor is providing the correct input to the Control Module.
    b. Validation:
        i. Conduct field testing to ensure that the Vehicle Speed Sensor is providing accurate input to the Control Module in real-world driving conditions.
        ii. Verify that the Vehicle Speed Sensor is functioning properly in all driving scenarios (e.g. merging, changing lanes, driving on the highway).

6. Warning Signal Indicator:
    a. Verification:
        i. Test the Warning Signal Indicator to ensure that it is generating the visual or audible warning signal properly.
        ii. Verify that the Warning Signal Indicator is activated when there is a vehicle in the blind spot.
        iii. Conduct testing to ensure that the Warning Signal Indicator is visible or audible to the driver under different weather and lighting conditions.
    b. Validation:
        i. Conduct field testing to ensure that the Warning Signal Indicator is visible or audible to the driver in real-world driving conditions.
        ii. Verify that the Warning Signal Indicator is effective in alerting the driver of the presence of a vehicle in the blind spot.

Overall System Validation:
    a. Conduct testing to ensure that the Blind Spot Monitoring System is functioning properly in all driving scenarios.
    b. Verify that the system is providing accurate warnings to the driver and aiding in the prevention of collisions.
    c. Conduct field testing to ensure that the Blind Spot Monitoring System is effective in real-world driving conditions.
    d. Verify that the system is compatible with other safety systems in the vehicle.

Vehicle_Description: Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vechicle with short turn radius and good navigability
Stakeholder_Requirement: Safety: Equipped with necessary safety features
System_Requirement: Rearview Camera: Provides a clear view of the area behind the vehicle, helping the driver to reverse and park safely
System_Architecture:
The architecture of the Rearview Camera for the Compact hatchback 2 seater urban mobility vehicle consists of several components that allow the driver to have a clear view of the area behind the vehicle while reversing and parking. Here's a detailed layout of the architecture:

1. Camera: The Rearview Camera is a small, weatherproof camera mounted on the rear of the vehicle. It captures a wide-angle view of the area behind the vehicle and sends the video feed to the display unit in the dashboard.

2. Display Unit: The display unit is a screen mounted on the dashboard that shows the video feed from the Rearview Camera. It can be either a standalone display or integrated into the vehicle's infotainment system.

3. Control Module: The Control Module is responsible for processing the video feed from the Rearview Camera and displaying it on the dashboard. It also handles additional features like distance markers, parking guidelines, and low-light visibility enhancements.

4. Wiring Harness: The wiring harness connects the camera and the control module to the power supply and the display unit. It also facilitates the transfer of data between these components.

To map the interaction among components:

When the driver engages the reverse gear, the Rearview Camera is activated => The Camera captures the view behind the vehicle and sends the video feed to the Control Module => The Control Module processes the video feed and displays it on the Display Unit => The driver can now see the area behind the vehicle on the Display Unit, allowing them to reverse and park safely.

The Control Module also provides additional features like distance markers, parking guidelines, and low-light visibility enhancements, which help the driver to park accurately and safely. The Wiring Harness facilitates the transfer of power and data between the Camera, Control Module, and Display Unit, ensuring seamless operation of the Rearview Camera.
VandV_Plan:
